One of Smite‚Äôs greatest strengths is its diverse roster of gods drawn from world mythology. From the familiar Greek and Norse pantheons to the rich traditions of Hindu, Egyptian, Japanese, and Celtic legends, the game offers an impressive variety of characters and playstyles. Whether you prefer the precision of assassins, the power of mages, the resilience of tanks, or the steady damage of hunters, each god feels distinct and thoughtfully crafted. Their abilities not only fit their roles but also reflect their mythological origins, adding an extra layer of depth and excitement for fans of lore and history

I‚Äôve had a lot of fun playing Smite. The gameplay is great, especially when you‚Äôre playing with friends. It‚Äôs a blast to team up and take on other players. The gods and abilities are cool, and the matches can get pretty intense.

That said, sometimes the game feels a little unbalanced. Some gods are way stronger than others, and it can get frustrating. Also, it feels like the company cares more about releasing skins than fixing those balance issues or improving the game. Honestly, we didn‚Äôt need a Smite 2‚Äîthe first one still has a lot of potential.

Overall, it‚Äôs a fun game, but it could be better if the focus shifted more to fixing balance and making the core experience better.

Only about 33 hours in and honestly, I was terrible. A friend suggested I try it, and while I had some fun, I never really got past being bad at it. If I‚Äôd stuck around, I definitely would‚Äôve mained KuKulKan, dropping giant tornadoes on people never got old.

It‚Äôs a solid game if MOBAs are your thing, but it wasn‚Äôt quite for me.
This game accurately depicted Jesus kicking the prophet Muhammad's ass. Handily. Low diff.

Smite is an exhilarating take on MOBAs. Playing as gods like Thor, Medusa, or Sun Wukong feels epic, and the third-person perspective makes every battle more intense. Whether you‚Äôre diving into casual Arena matches or climbing the competitive ladder, the game is fast-paced, strategic, and endlessly fun.

‚ÄúSMITE: Where gods clash, friendships die, and you realize you‚Äôre not as divine as you thought.‚Äù

You start thinking, ‚ÄúCool, I can play as Zeus!‚Äù ‚Äî ten minutes later, you‚Äôre being juggled by a monkey, melted by Ra, and insulted by a twelve-year-old who just called you ‚Äútrash‚Äù before ulting your corpse.

It‚Äôs chaotic, unbalanced, occasionally rage-inducing... and somehow I can‚Äôt stop playing. 
The gameplay slaps harder than Thor‚Äôs hammer, and every match feels like a mix of divine glory and emotional trauma. 
The graphics are solid, the gods are varied, and every new skin tempts your wallet like a siren song from Hades himself.

Sure, the matchmaking sometimes feels like it was designed by Loki on a bad day, but when your team actually coordinates? Pure serotonin.

9/10 ‚Äî Would queue again, cry again, and pretend it was ‚Äúlag‚Äù again. ‚ö°

negative.review:
This is going to be a long one, but as a long-time player of Smite over a couple different platforms, I cannot in good faith continue to play or recommend Smite or the company it belongs to.

Smite 1 was one of the best MOBA games of it's time. If you didn't like top-down camera perspective games like League of Legends but still wanted an expansive array of characters, play-styles and items to fit any niche your team needs, Smite had you covered. The skin economy in the game was definitely a struggle as the game boasts many, may Gods to play as and each have a handful of skins accompanying them. Some of these skins are cheap recolors which is totally fine to include, however some of the 'rarer' skins could cost you so much of the premium currency you could not obtain them without paying. Sure, skins are not a necessity of the gameplay and are purely cosmetic, but it's still something that should be pointed out.

Gameplay-wise, the game did have flaws. New characters were undeniably buffed to increase attention on newly released content. Nerfs were given to characters who did not deserve them and making them difficult to play. There was heavy favoritism from devs towards certain Gods in both game-play and attention. It's fine for characters like Neith or Zeus, because they are more-or-less the faces of the game, both being Gods that were part of the game since beta. But after a God was introduced, played by the community for a week and nerfed after the initial hype, you would likely never see a skin, official mention or people play that character for months, years and sometimes never.

Now, I will admit that I do have a skill issue with the game and cannot handle pvp matches well, so I tend to gravitate towards bot matches. Despite this, I have played many pvp matches and... I did not enjoy my stay in them... Toxic players, reported for "cheating" if you just.. do well in the game? Reported for "feeding" if you just aren't doing too well in a match and end up dying a couple times. I only really enjoyed my pvp match experience with friends and the rare lobby with teammates who either didn't talk or were cool. Smite has a massive botting issue now, they do not care about Smite 1 anymore and it shows. It was obvious from the moment updates started to stall and then, Smite 2 was announced and I could feel the downfall coming from a mile away.

Smite 2 is a CLUSTERF*** of awful optimization, company choices and gameplay flops. Trust me, it is NOT worth it to play the second game. I have probably paid upwards of $200 on Smite 1 over my years and years of playing (I know, I know, I need to touch grass..). Anyways, Smite 2 assured people that our skins and premium currency in Smite 1 would be rewarded. And rewarded we were! With an amount of cross-game skins you can count on one hand that look awful and porting our premium currency into a fraction of common currency- Thanks.. I feel so rewarded right now.. I could only buy 1 new skin with the currency I was awarded from that.

Now, I do want to keep my review of Smite 1 unbiased and fair, but with all of the things that have happened to this game and the choices of the company, I can't help but feel jaded, angry and saddened that the game I played with my friends, the game I spent money on, the game I played for hours and the game I loved and said was my favorite game for YEARS, has become a massive pile of rubbish and shattered hope. I really did want to continue playing Smite for years more, but I haven't played in over a year now and I don't miss the Smite I left behind. I will forever mourn the Smite that I loved and grew up with.

Terrible scaling, terrible player community. If you enjoy having people on your team who quit or go afk after dying 2 times then this is the game for you. If you aren't playing 4v5 because someone on your side quit then prepare for a 4v6 since they will feed on purpose. No need to worry about the consequences for such behavior either, Smite made sure that in all the years it has existed there is none! Also the most toxic player base in all of gaming history. If you die you can guarantee at least 1 person on your side to spam click you and tell you"you rock". This game had a lot of potential but the devs ignored all the real problems, and put all their time into creating skins. Eventually they just said decided to throw this game away and make Smite 2 where the biggest change was better graphics. Everything about this game has been a joke and I pray that nobody has to deal with the awful game known as Smite.
terrible game, incompetent programmers, crooked company stay away
If Hi-Rez turned had a PvE game mode available, I think it would do wonders for the people still playing. Otherwise, this is a rough game to play with anyone, let alone with friends.
Unplayable. Queue times are often 20+ minutes, and getting any help from support is incredibly frustrating.

If you enjoy repeat non sense and feeling like you're wasting your time, this is your game. Also the creators are super over the top LGBTQ+ activists so yeah have fun with that.

Ruined the game by making Smite 2. Management doesn't care about smite 1 anymore, game is plagued with speed hackers and a toxic player base. Regardless whether you report them or even your entire team of 5 reports them the degenerate team at Hi-Rez is either under payed, laid off, has some kind of brain damage or them, themselves are the very ones exploiting the game. One of these has to be the reason the ban hammer never comes, with this being said i would not recommend this game to anyone even after having almost 1300 hours played on just this one account. Hi-Rez has went down the toilet with their companies direction and for the sake of STEAM and the players I hope it stays there.

Dead game, Garbage company.

I used to play this game a lot about five years ago ‚Äì nearly 500 hours back then. I really enjoyed it, even bought some skins and had a lot of good memories with it. The gameplay was solid, the concept unique, and at that time I never regretted spending so much time or money in it.

So after all these years I thought: why not give it another try? I‚Äôd seen a lot of reviews saying the community had gone downhill, but I wanted to check for myself.

Well‚Ä¶ it didn‚Äôt take long to find out. In my very first match, people were already flaming each other during god selection. No teamwork, no fun, just insults flying around before the game even started. And once the match began, it only got worse ‚Äì within five minutes people were already trash talking and throwing insults around.

I finished the game, but honestly that was it for me. One match was enough to realize this isn‚Äôt the same game I used to enjoy. Maybe I just had bad luck with teammates, but when your very first experience after years away is already that toxic, you know what to expect.

The sad thing is: the game itself is still good. The concept works, the mechanics are fun ‚Äì all the ingredients for a great time are there. But the community? Completely toxic. It feels a lot like League of Legends in that way: a good game ruined by the people playing it.

If you‚Äôre looking for something to relax with after work, forget it. The atmosphere is just too negative to be enjoyable. And that‚Äôs a shame, because I really wanted to like this game again.

TL;DR Final thoughts: great game, ruined by its community. For me, this one match after five years was both a disappointing return and my final goodbye.

Smite 1 > Smite 2

Smite 2  might have more fancy graphics but nothing more.. so sad the game studio tried to kill their very own child for the next one :(
Good game but bad CEO,  the game is not receiving updates, and is slowly dying. RIP smite

So in 2023 after almost 1000 hours in 7 years of playing Smite with many breaks in between and returning from time to time to see how things have changed I finally quit for good. I had amazing times with this game and I had times where I felt like I was wasting huge amounts of time with it.
If Hi-Rez turned had a PvE game mode available, I think it would do wonders for the people still playing. Otherwise, this is a rough game to play with anyone, let alone with friends.

dumb game that breaks most of the time, thank god i get penalized for your game not working, i see why this game is free lol

Hi-Rez takes the servers down for "maintenance" every 1,5h for about 3h. Strangely enough, after their maintenance, there are usually more bugs than before. My favorites include: Not being able to queue, not being able to join the game (loading-screen forever), being stuck in a Lobby after the game ended (with 6 other ppl) and not allowing me to reroll or trade in Assault, just to name a few. Furthermore, there are a bunch of Speedhackers by now because nobody is banning them anymore. 
The rest of the community is a mixed basket. About 1/3 of them are awesome people who teach and support you when you have a bad game. Another 1/3 just doesn't communicate at all, ever. The last 1/3 is taken straight out of a LoL. Most of them suck at the game and then start insulting teammates who are either new to the game or just don't do anything to defend themselves. In the end, they usually go afk while still flaming you, which leads to a lost match and lots of frustration. Especially if you queue with the same guy the next day because a whole Lobby reporting him for insults and toxicity is apparently not enough to get any reaction from the devs/mods.

Tl;dr: Servers are constantly down, community has become more toxic, more hackers. Hi-Rez is trying to smother Smite so that people play Smite 2.

I used to enjoy playing this game, but as a person who prefers playing a support position, this game has progressively gotten frustrating that I had to quit. Not because of bad games, or bad teammates, but because the identity of 'Support' has been streamlined to 'Tank' with no means of pressuring the enemy. Everything else has been nerfed or reworked against Guardian's and off-Warrior support that it was relegating 4 of your 6 items, and the remaining two had to be more defense items or else your team is disparaged because it isn't 'meta'.

A big problem that comes with this fixation is that assassins built enough Armor Penetration, your defenses lose most of their value. Most items that could have made Guardian's functional to apply pressure or peal potential got nerfed or outright restricted.

I can't recommend this game or its sequel when the developers don't have a clear vision of the most underserved and generally important position, but maybe when the next Assassin or Mage drops they'll figure out how to make support fun.

"It's not a waste of time if you enjoy it" 

Well, unfortunately, it's slowly become a clear, definitive, waste of time. 

Other reviews have pointed out: 
- Abandoned game 
- Smite 2 is awful 
- They want money 
- Toxic 
- No support and no new content 

The last two points are the worst - people will genuinely hate you, sabotage the game, and give up in almost every game. It doesn't matter if you're winning by 6k gold, if the enemy has a DC, hell - if the game is dead even and it's a fun one, your teammates will find a way to complain. 

The toxicity part is the worst because, before, if someone hurled slurs at someone, then they'd be reported - and the next day or so, it would say "an action has been taken against a player you reported." That's great!

That never happens anymore. 

People are saying, and behaving, way worse, as more quit and I haven't gotten one of those messages in a long time. The lack of support in an already toxic fan base is killer. Play something else.

I played a little smite when it was in beta and quit when they ruined jungling.

Why am I being shown a EULA for AMD CPU drivers? Why would SMITE need this? I rejected it and it launched anyway 

Anyway, Hi-Rez were too late to the party here. Hero Shooters got popular right after this and ate SMITE's lunch. Then they made a hero shooter a little too late to that party, too. Then they made a battle royale a little late to that party... what CAN'T they get wrong?

Dead game, Garbage company.

I used to play this game a lot about five years ago ‚Äì nearly 500 hours back then. I really enjoyed it, even bought some skins and had a lot of good memories with it. The gameplay was solid, the concept unique, and at that time I never regretted spending so much time or money in it.

So after all these years I thought: why not give it another try? I‚Äôd seen a lot of reviews saying the community had gone downhill, but I wanted to check for myself.

Well‚Ä¶ it didn‚Äôt take long to find out. In my very first match, people were already flaming each other during god selection. No teamwork, no fun, just insults flying around before the game even started. And once the match began, it only got worse ‚Äì within five minutes people were already trash talking and throwing insults around.

I finished the game, but honestly that was it for me. One match was enough to realize this isn‚Äôt the same game I used to enjoy. Maybe I just had bad luck with teammates, but when your very first experience after years away is already that toxic, you know what to expect.

The sad thing is: the game itself is still good. The concept works, the mechanics are fun ‚Äì all the ingredients for a great time are there. But the community? Completely toxic. It feels a lot like League of Legends in that way: a good game ruined by the people playing it.

If you‚Äôre looking for something to relax with after work, forget it. The atmosphere is just too negative to be enjoyable. And that‚Äôs a shame, because I really wanted to like this game again.

TL;DR Final thoughts: great game, ruined by its community. For me, this one match after five years was both a disappointing return and my final goodbye.

This is going to be a long one, but as a long-time player of Smite over a couple different platforms, I cannot in good faith continue to play or recommend Smite or the company it belongs to.

Smite 1 was one of the best MOBA games of it's time. If you didn't like top-down camera perspective games like League of Legends but still wanted an expansive array of characters, play-styles and items to fit any niche your team needs, Smite had you covered. The skin economy in the game was definitely a struggle as the game boasts many, may Gods to play as and each have a handful of skins accompanying them. Some of these skins are cheap recolors which is totally fine to include, however some of the 'rarer' skins could cost you so much of the premium currency you could not obtain them without paying. Sure, skins are not a necessity of the gameplay and are purely cosmetic, but it's still something that should be pointed out.

Gameplay-wise, the game did have flaws. New characters were undeniably buffed to increase attention on newly released content. Nerfs were given to characters who did not deserve them and making them difficult to play. There was heavy favoritism from devs towards certain Gods in both game-play and attention. It's fine for characters like Neith or Zeus, because they are more-or-less the faces of the game, both being Gods that were part of the game since beta. But after a God was introduced, played by the community for a week and nerfed after the initial hype, you would likely never see a skin, official mention or people play that character for months, years and sometimes never.

Now, I will admit that I do have a skill issue with the game and cannot handle pvp matches well, so I tend to gravitate towards bot matches. Despite this, I have played many pvp matches and... I did not enjoy my stay in them... Toxic players, reported for "cheating" if you just.. do well in the game? Reported for "feeding" if you just aren't doing too well in a match and end up dying a couple times. I only really enjoyed my pvp match experience with friends and the rare lobby with teammates who either didn't talk or were cool. Smite has a massive botting issue now, they do not care about Smite 1 anymore and it shows. It was obvious from the moment updates started to stall and then, Smite 2 was announced and I could feel the downfall coming from a mile away.

Smite 2 is a CLUSTERF*** of awful optimization, company choices and gameplay flops. Trust me, it is NOT worth it to play the second game. I have probably paid upwards of $200 on Smite 1 over my years and years of playing (I know, I know, I need to touch grass..). Anyways, Smite 2 assured people that our skins and premium currency in Smite 1 would be rewarded. And rewarded we were! With an amount of cross-game skins you can count on one hand that look awful and porting our premium currency into a fraction of common currency- Thanks.. I feel so rewarded right now.. I could only buy 1 new skin with the currency I was awarded from that.

Now, I do want to keep my review of Smite 1 unbiased and fair, but with all of the things that have happened to this game and the choices of the company, I can't help but feel jaded, angry and saddened that the game I played with my friends, the game I spent money on, the game I played for hours and the game I loved and said was my favorite game for YEARS, has become a massive pile of rubbish and shattered hope. I really did want to continue playing Smite for years more, but I haven't played in over a year now and I don't miss the Smite I left behind. I will forever mourn the Smite that I loved and grew up with.

Terrible scaling, terrible player community. If you enjoy having people on your team who quit or go afk after dying 2 times then this is the game for you. If you aren't playing 4v5 because someone on your side quit then prepare for a 4v6 since they will feed on purpose. No need to worry about the consequences for such behavior either, Smite made sure that in all the years it has existed there is none! Also the most toxic player base in all of gaming history. If you die you can guarantee at least 1 person on your side to spam click you and tell you"you rock". This game had a lot of potential but the devs ignored all the real problems, and put all their time into creating skins. Eventually they just said decided to throw this game away and make Smite 2 where the biggest change was better graphics. Everything about this game has been a joke and I pray that nobody has to deal with the awful game known as Smite.

Hi-Rez takes the servers down for "maintenance" every 1,5h for about 3h. Strangely enough, after their maintenance, there are usually more bugs than before. My favorites include: Not being able to queue, not being able to join the game (loading-screen forever), being stuck in a Lobby after the game ended (with 6 other ppl) and not allowing me to reroll or trade in Assault, just to name a few. Furthermore, there are a bunch of Speedhackers by now because nobody is banning them anymore. 
The rest of the community is a mixed basket. About 1/3 of them are awesome people who teach and support you when you have a bad game. Another 1/3 just doesn't communicate at all, ever. The last 1/3 is taken straight out of a LoL. Most of them suck at the game and then start insulting teammates who are either new to the game or just don't do anything to defend themselves. In the end, they usually go afk while still flaming you, which leads to a lost match and lots of frustration. Especially if you queue with the same guy the next day because a whole Lobby reporting him for insults and toxicity is apparently not enough to get any reaction from the devs/mods.

Tl;dr: Servers are constantly down, community has become more toxic, more hackers. Hi-Rez is trying to smother Smite so that people play Smite 2.

I used to enjoy playing this game, but as a person who prefers playing a support position, this game has progressively gotten frustrating that I had to quit. Not because of bad games, or bad teammates, but because the identity of 'Support' has been streamlined to 'Tank' with no means of pressuring the enemy. Everything else has been nerfed or reworked against Guardian's and off-Warrior support that it was relegating 4 of your 6 items, and the remaining two had to be more defense items or else your team is disparaged because it isn't 'meta'.

A big problem that comes with this fixation is that assassins built enough Armor Penetration, your defenses lose most of their value. Most items that could have made Guardian's functional to apply pressure or peal potential got nerfed or outright restricted.

I can't recommend this game or its sequel when the developers don't have a clear vision of the most underserved and generally important position, but maybe when the next Assassin or Mage drops they'll figure out how to make support fun.

"It's not a waste of time if you enjoy it" 

Well, unfortunately, it's slowly become a clear, definitive, waste of time. 

Other reviews have pointed out: 
- Abandoned game 
- Smite 2 is awful 
- They want money 
- Toxic 
- No support and no new content 

The last two points are the worst - people will genuinely hate you, sabotage the game, and give up in almost every game. It doesn't matter if you're winning by 6k gold, if the enemy has a DC, hell - if the game is dead even and it's a fun one, your teammates will find a way to complain. 

The toxicity part is the worst because, before, if someone hurled slurs at someone, then they'd be reported - and the next day or so, it would say "an action has been taken against a player you reported." That's great!

That never happens anymore. 

People are saying, and behaving, way worse, as more quit and I haven't gotten one of those messages in a long time. The lack of support in an already toxic fan base is killer. Play something else.

I played a little smite when it was in beta and quit when they ruined jungling.
